p9
  • p9

Timezones in Pandas

pandas
timezones
Author

Damien Martin

Published

October 27, 2024

On this page

  • Problem
  • Solution
  • Example

Problem

Pandas has it’s on version of datetimes. If you recieve a datetime in UTC (but only because you know it from context, not because it was labelled), how do you

  • assign a timezone
  • convert from one timezone to another

Solution

Use the datetime series accessor on a series s of datetime values:

  • s.dt.tz_localize("tz name as string") to attach a timezone to a series that does not already have one
  • s.dt.tz_convert("new tz name as string") to convert from the existing timezone to the new one specified

Example

Let’s artifically create a dataframe for a ghost on Hallowe’en, logging the days events. When converting to a datetime, we could add a timezone, but we won’t do that here (emulating the case when you get a timezone out of a database).

import pandas as pd 

daily_ghoul_report = pd.DataFrame([
    {'event': 'breakfast', 'timestamp': '2024-10-31 08:00:00'},
    {'event': 'go to work', 'timestamp': '2024-10-31 09:00:00'},
    {'event': 'project X', 'timestamp': '2024-10-31 11:00:00'},
    {'event': 'finish work', 'timestamp': '2024-10-31 18:00:00'},
    {'event': 'haunt houses', 'timestamp': '2024-10-31 22:00:00'}
])
daily_ghoul_report['timestamp'] = pd.to_datetime(daily_ghoul_report['timestamp'])

Let’s say that we knew this event happened in Salem, Massachusettes. Let’s assign the correct timestamp

daily_ghoul_report['timestamp'] = daily_ghoul_report['timestamp'].dt.tz_localize('US/Eastern')
daily_ghoul_report
event timestamp
0 breakfast 2024-10-31 08:00:00-04:00
1 go to work 2024-10-31 09:00:00-04:00
2 project X 2024-10-31 11:00:00-04:00
3 finish work 2024-10-31 18:00:00-04:00
4 haunt houses 2024-10-31 22:00:00-04:00

The UTC offset has now been applied! Note this is not idempotent; if you try to tz_localize a timestamp that already has a timezone/UTC offset, then you will get an error.

This is because a tz_localize is supposed to make a timezone without changing the values of the times. If you have a timezone and you want the same time in a different timezone, you’ll want to convert using tz_convert (which changes the offset and the time, so that you are still referring to the same time in UTC).

Let’s convert to the Pacific timezone:

daily_ghoul_report['pacific_time'] = daily_ghoul_report['timestamp'].dt.tz_convert('US/Pacific')

daily_ghoul_report
event timestamp pacific_time
0 breakfast 2024-10-31 08:00:00-04:00 2024-10-31 05:00:00-07:00
1 go to work 2024-10-31 09:00:00-04:00 2024-10-31 06:00:00-07:00
2 project X 2024-10-31 11:00:00-04:00 2024-10-31 08:00:00-07:00
3 finish work 2024-10-31 18:00:00-04:00 2024-10-31 15:00:00-07:00
4 haunt houses 2024-10-31 22:00:00-04:00 2024-10-31 19:00:00-07:00

Important timezones you might want to use * UTC * US/Eastern * US/Central * US/Mountain * US/Pacific * NZ

To find a list of supported timezones, you can use the following code snippet:

import pytz  # What pandas uses under the hood

sorted(pytz.all_timezones_set)
